triples.name: Motion planning
triples.relevance: Path planning algorithms are fundamental motion planning methods used to guide robots to destinations safely and efficiently.

triples.name: Mobile robot
triples.relevance: Mobile robots are a primary application domain for path planning algorithms in autonomous navigation.

triples.name: Unmanned aerial vehicle
triples.relevance: Unmanned aerial vehicles require path planning algorithms to autonomously navigate and complete missions.

triples.name: Self-driving car
triples.relevance: Autonomous cars depend on path planning algorithms to determine collision-free routes in dynamic traffic environments.

triples.name: Collision detection
triples.relevance: Collision detection is essential for ensuring path planning algorithms generate collision-free trajectories.

triples.name: Holonomic constraints
triples.relevance: Holonomic constraints describe motion limitations in robot kinematics that path planning algorithms must accommodate.

triples.name: Nonholonomic system
triples.relevance: Non-holonomic constraints impose velocity-based limitations on mobile robots that path planning algorithms must handle.

triples.name: Robot navigation
triples.relevance: Robot navigation is the overarching task that path planning algorithms enable by determining safe point-to-point routes.
